body: She is loath to go into detail, but Amanda M. Burden is clearly not crazy about the design for a Jets stadium on the Far West Side of Manhattan. As director of the City Planning Department, she has built her reputation on concern for aesthetics: how a building looks, how it relates to the street, how it serves the people who use its public spaces.
title: An Aesthetic Watchdog in the City Planning Office

body: Looking to address a critical shortage of housing for low- and moderate-income New Yorkers, city officials are planning to let developers put up larger buildings along the long-neglected north Brooklyn waterfront in return for setting aside up to a quarter of the apartments as lower-cost units. The concept, called inclusionary zoning, will face a
title: City Sees Way to Get Mix of Homes on Brooklyn Waterfront

body: Consuelo Ruybal and Oraia Reid looked out the windows of their sport utility vehicle, scanning the dark doorways on Johnson Avenue in Brooklyn for an address. Early on a recent Sunday morning, they were driving along a deserted street in East Williamsburg lined with warehouses. Ms. Ruybal drove while Ms. Reid navigated, clutching a map and a
title: Williamsburg Journal; A Free Ride For Women, By Women, Late at Night

body: WEATHER BIRD: Jazz at the Dawnof Its Second Century By Gary Giddins Oxford University Press ($35, hardcover) If you visit Des Moines and you go to a bar where someone is playing luminous piano in the manner of Hank Jones, you may feel you have stumbled into heaven. In New York, that same someone would be just a guy who plays Hank Jones; we've
title: NEW YORK BOOKSHELF/NONFICTION; Celebrating Jazz, Columbia And Some Really Great Apartments

body: HAVING spent college summers in New York, Manu Sawkar knew that finding a more permanent place to live wouldn't be easy. One serendipitous summer, he rented a room from a man he met on a plane. One miserable summer, a Web listing led him to a tiny, noisy, overpriced room with a roommate who hated him. In the fall, finished with college and planning
title: THE HUNT; Three Guys and the 'Perfect-Tenant' Ideal

body: According to the 1941 Crown edition of the Escoffier cookbook, tripes à la mode de Caen is best prepared with the tripe proper: ''the Paunch (first stomach), the Honey-comb Bag (second stomach), the Manyplies (third stomach), and the Reed (real stomach).'' It helped to have the great chef at my fingertips when thinking about the work of Pinar
title: A Shelf Life So Short It Takes the Breath Away

body: IN the final year of the HBO hit series ''Sex and the City,'' the character Carrie Bradshaw and her Prada-touting friends experienced a number of firsts: Charlotte converted to Judaism and settled into a happy marriage with Harry; Samantha let a man into her heart; and Carrie finally saw the Eiffel Tower and, it appears, snagged Mr. Big -- maybe
title: 'Outer Borough' Finally Attracts The 'In' Crowd

body: The man's face, blank and square-jawed under a knit hat, peers out from ''Wanted'' posters along Bedford Avenue in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. He is being sought by the police in connection with a recent sexual attack in the neighborhood and a rape in nearby Greenpoint, and he is making women in the area nervous. The police said that the mid-afternoon
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WILLIAMSBURG/GREENPOINT; A Spate of Attacks Has Women Looking Over Their Shoulders

body: ELLSWORTH KELLY, his shirt hanging over his paint-splattered jeans, stood in the doorway of his snow-white gallery and flipped some switches. Slowly, louvers in the pitched skylight shifted and the six new paintings on the walls blazed with color. Designed by the architect Richard Gluckman, this 25-by-50-foot space lies at the southern end of the
title: ARCHITECTURE; The Artists' Architect, Building For Art's Sake

body: A man who attacked and raped a woman in Greenpoint last week also committed an earlier sexual assault in Brooklyn, the police said yesterday. The most recent attack occurred last Thursday, the police said, when the man, dressed in a beige jacket, beige hat and clean-shaven, entered a cellphone store in Greenpoint and raped the 22-year-old clerk,
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Sought In Rapes

body: The promoter was heavyset, balding, clean-shaven, round-faced and smooth-skinned. When he approached his marks, he was blunt but also unpredictable -- he would show up late for meetings, sometimes with a cane, sometimes not. It was all part of the game. ''Charming would have blown the whole thing,'' said one of his intended marks, Elliott Bey. But
title: A Brooklyn Con Game Victim Stings Back

body: A woman working alone in a Greenpoint cellphone store was raped at gunpoint yesterday afternoon, the police said. The 22-year-old woman, whose identity was not released, was treated at Woodhull Hospital for injuries. The attacker, who took a number of cellphones when he left shortly after 2:30 p.m., is described as clean shaven, 25 or 30 years old,
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman Raped In Cellphone Store

body: LATE on a recent Saturday night in the subway station underneath Nassau Avenue in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, a long-awaited G train pulled up to the platform, drawing applause and a short little dance from two relieved young women who had been waiting. The applause was tinged with sarcasm, and it was typical. The subway line, which weaves its way
title: URBAN TACTICS; The Cinderella Train

body: The notion of shopping for minimalist furniture while nibbling Swedish meatballs within view of the Statue of Liberty took a major step forward yesterday as a City Council panel approved a plan for what is likely to become New York City's first Ikea, along the Brooklyn waterfront in Red Hook. The approval came despite opposition from some residents
title: Panel Approves Plan by Ikea To Open Store In Red Hook

body: It may be difficult to grasp how flushing the toilet could be considered a political act. Yet gallons upon gallons of waste that enter the city's sewer system every day must go someplace, and deciding where, and how it arrives there, can be deeply contentious. Take the neighborhoods of western Queens, which learned at a meeting of Community Board 1
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: QUEENS; From Murky Depths, Angst

body: New York City's commercial waste, much of which is now shipped through the Bronx and Brooklyn, will instead be directed to a marine transfer station on the West Side of Manhattan under a plan announced yesterday by the Bloomberg administration. The announcement is the first installment of a larger plan that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will release
title: City Proposes Shipping Trash Via West Side

body: In retrospect, the 15-foot fence, made of corrugated sheet metal topped with razor wire, seemed a strange feature for a used-car business. But that was one of the first things the owners of Astra Motor Cars installed immediately upon moving into their sprawling lot in East Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The business's spartan decorating style was just one
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST WILLIAMSBURG; Where a Good Fence Makes Skeptical Neighbors

body: HER name is Maria Piedad Cano, but friends call her Piedad. ''There are so many Marias where I'm from,'' she said, chuckling, as she slathered margarine over Colombian corncakes sizzling on a propane-powered griddle. It was 10:45 p.m., and the Friday night bar crowd on Roosevelt Avenue hovered hungrily around her sidewalk kitchen. An hour earlier
title: Street Corner Cooks Have Names, Too

author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: UNLIKE people who search intently for the ideal home, Caroline and David Gould realized early on they were willing to settle for something good enough. ''We didn't want to be one of those couples who looked for the perfect apartment for a year,'' Ms. Gould said. ''A lot of people look at a trillion things. We looked at maybe 10. It was more about
title: THE HUNT; Climbing the Ladder, One Rung at a Time

body: More than 300 bicyclists were arrested during the demonstrations against the Republican National Convention. While the riders were released within days, many of their bikes have been locked up for three weeks. Yesterday, the Manhattan district attorney's office agreed to let protesters retrieve them from the property clerk in Greenpoint, Brooklyn.
title: Police Allow The Return Of Bicycles From Rallies

body: Raising the pressure as Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg prepares to release his 20-year waste management plan, city lawmakers and community advocates said yesterday that the city should use barges rather than trucks to move commercial trash to out-of-state landfills. The mayor has already said he intends to use barges for residential waste, but he has
title: Mayor Is Urged to Use Barges To Carry Commercial Trash

body: ON a recent Sunday afternoon, Alison Moritsugu and her husband, Stefan Petrik, leaned against their Honda Civic, talking in the driveway in front of their brick-red ranch house. The open garage door revealed a tarp-covered motorcycle and a woodworking shop -- a typical weekend scene in cul-de-sac New York. But they don't conform with most people's
title: Moving Out, Seeking the Next SoHo

body: For 16 years, the hard work of what prosecutors are calling a huge chop-shop operation took place on the streets and inside a gritty industrial building in Brooklyn, where the windows were barred and barbed-wire fences kept strangers out. But the fruits of that labor bloomed in suburbia, federal prosecutors said yesterday in announcing the
title: U.S. Indicts 11 in Chop Shop In Brooklyn Worth Millions

body: Some consumers have crossed farm-raised salmon off their shopping lists for environmental and health reasons. But what kind of smoked salmon are they buying? Western smoked salmon is usually from wild fish caught in Washington or Alaska. Acme Smoked Fish in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, is now cold-smoking wild sockeye from the Pacific Northwest that's
title: FOOD STUFF; Stalking the Wild Salmon

body: ''The Comfort and Safety of Your Own Home,'' a mood piece written and directed by Josh Fox, is not one of those plays in which you settle into your chair and passively let the actors take over for a few hours. Mr. Fox, one of the most adventurous impresarios of the New York avant-garde, keeps the audience moving through the entire show, constantly
title: THEATER REVIEW; Home, Terrifying Home: The Not-So-Scenic Tour

body: MICHAEL SINGER, a 58-year-old artist, sat in the doorway of a Japanese-style pavilion he built on a pond here and talked about beavers. In particular he was talking about their drive to fell trees to expand their territory. ''The more they flood, the more habitat they have,'' Mr. Singer said. ''When they're in water, they're safe from predators.''
title: NATURE; The Woodlands as a Canvas

body: THEIR words struggled for posterity above the cacophony of Foley Square, the swooshes of cars, the gargles of a fountain, the faint but constant breaths of a city alive. But Sheryl Oring, sitting posture-perfect at her moveable office, nailed each word down with the tiny hammers of her Erika typewriter. Sitting yesterday in the open-air bazaar of
title: About New York; A Salute to Free Speech, And the Freedom Not to Listen

body: Like everyone who experienced it, Tom Keefe has a story to share about last year's extensive blackout. His involved a missed job interview, an eccentric new landlord, several East Village bars and a chin covered with stubble. Now Mr. Keefe, an aspiring filmmaker, can add another twist to his tale. Tomorrow, on the first anniversary of the blackout
title: A Year After the Big Blackout, a Film Festival Flickers to Life

body: HANG around enough old salts, and sooner or later one of them will recount his favorite recipe for bluefish: Nail a few fillets to a plank of seasoned hardwood, stick them over a fire, and when their edges crisp and curl, throw away the fish and eat the plank. The punch line sums up the way most people feel about bluefish. But in a city where menus
title: With a Bit Of Love, The Blues Are Just Fine

body: The authorities are looking for two men who forced a woman into a car from a street in Greenpoint early Monday morning, robbed her and raped her, the police said yesterday. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Two Sought In Robbery And Rape

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CANARSIE; For Some in a Proud Neighborhood, a Free Gift Bears Too High a Price

body: THE hulking, cone-shaped stainless steel tanks in this Brooklyn warehouse loom like missiles, but only a paranoid teetotaler could mistake their contents for weapons of mass destruction. What the tanks actually contain are ales and lagers, tens of thousands of gallons of the golden liquids, all patiently fermenting inside a former Borden's dairy
title: PUBLIC LIVES; Brewing a Plain Old Favorite in Brooklyn

body: The crack of the home-team bat echoes once again over Brooklyn. Cruise liners may soon steam away from the shores of Red Hook. title: Rheingold's Homecoming: Brewed Again in Brooklyn

body: Few rules govern the Brooklyn Kickball league, but one is certain: you are not allowed to bunt. It makes getting on base way too easy. In this baseball-like game, however, you are allowed to shout scathing insults at your opponents, get into fake brawls with them and generally behave like a third-grader. And of course, it's much more fun to do all
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENPOINT; Grown-Up Kickballers Find Their Inner Third-Grader

body: Julie Verardi sat in front of a panel of four judges at the Crystal Room in South Beach, Staten Island, her posture straight, her answers clear. ''It's important for me to know where I came from,'' Ms. Verardi, a freshman at the School of Visual Arts, told the panel. ''My mom's always trying to do the polka with me.'' ''What's your favorite food?''
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: STATEN ISLAND UP CLOSE; A New Miss Polonia Reigns Over a Growing Polish Stronghold

body: THE East River has been the city's digestive system. Unlike its sparkling sibling, the Hudson, it has belched with industry for years and unflinchingly done its part in processing the city's solid waste. Now, as developers are spending $4.25 billion to create more than 2.3 million square feet of office space and 6,000 units of housing along the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST SIDE; As the East River Is Transformed, Industrial Nostalgia Takes Hold

body: The dense clustering of waste processing operations in several neighborhoods outside Manhattan does not cause major environmental damage to the surrounding communities, a long-expected study of commercial waste disposal has concluded. At the same time, the study, to be released today, recommends stricter controls on pollution, noise and odors,
title: Controls on Odor and Noise Urged for Trash Stations

body: The future of Red Hook, Brooklyn, a port and industrial area since the Civil War, may have been sealed last December, when the decision was made to convert a hulking six-story warehouse on Imlay Street, next to a container port, into 150 luxury condominiums with a dramatic view of the harbor and the Manhattan skyline. The move was cheered by some
title: A Zoning Board's Quiet Work Has Neighbors Making Noise

body: Phyllis Yampolsky, an artist and community activist who has lived in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, since 1982, loves her neighborhood, and she loves being reminded of it even when she isn't there. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENPOINT; A Revered Name Survives, And With It Some Brooklyn Pride

title: State Panel Rejects Brooklyn Power Plant

title: Cake Masters

title: L.I. @ WORK; For North Fork's Chairman, It's Westward Ho!

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Officer Catches Robbery Suspect

title: Be It Ever So Low, the Basement Is Often Home

author: Robert Sullivan, who writes frequently for the magazine, is the author of ''Rats: Observations on the History and Habitat of the City's Most Unwanted Inhabitants,' to be published this spring by Bloomsbury and from which this article is adapted.
body: A short time after the World Trade Center came down, I went rat-trapping in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn with a couple of scientists from the New York City health department. title: Rat Tales

body: Early in the 17th century, Dutch settlers bought a large piece of land from the Maspet Indian tribe along what is now known as Newtown Creek. The tribe, whose name survives in the Queens neighborhood Maspeth, might have been eager to make the deal, given that they called the area ''at the bad water place.'' It is not known why they disparaged the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK WATERWAYS; Hike on Newtown Creek? It Isn't Quite That Awful

title: ART GUIDE

body: Sabato F. Catucci stalks the piers on the Red Hook waterfront in Brooklyn, where he has built a thriving business handling cargo containers, lumber, coffee and cacao beans. Mr. Catucci, the owner of American Stevedoring, has plans for a liquor distribution center on Pier 12, where his company would unload beer and spirits bound for Brooklyn, Queens
title: Is a Blue-Collar Future a Luxury on the Waterfront?

body: Richard Rednour spent the last week of his 28 years at the Domino Sugar plant in Brooklyn learning how to write a résumé. ''Network'' was among the other pieces of advice Mr. Rednour picked up this week at the employment classes the plant had offered to workers who will soon be re-entering the job market. Yesterday, the plant's owner, American
title: The Last Grain Falls at a Sugar Factory

body: A selective listing by critics of The Times: New or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the Northeast. Opera ''BORIS GODUNOV.'' August Everding's grandly realistic 1974 production of Mussorgsky's masterpiece has returned to the Met after six years' absence. On opening night most attention was focused on the acclaimed
title: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE

body: IF you say art and Brooklyn in the same sentence, you probably mean Williamsburg, which for about a decade has been the only viable alternative to Chelsea as a New York gallery scene. It's also an art neighborhood in the old, un-Chelsea way: artists live, work, kvetch and party there, even when their art commutes to Manhattan. Not that everything
title: ART REVIEW; Sampling Brooklyn, Keeper Of Eclectic Flames

body: FLICKERING before Amanda M. Burden, the city planning commissioner, was a vision of New York City of the future. A computer animation showed the view from a car driving toward the Greenpoint waterfront in Brooklyn. The industrial buildings were gone, replaced by a stately procession of five- and six-story brick and stone apartment buildings,
title: Remaking, or Preserving, the City's Face

author: E-mail: eating@nytimes.com
body: In a city well supplied with Italian, French and Chinese food -- not to mention almost every known cuisine -- these restaurants offer dishes you can't find on every block. title: GOOD EATING; Roads Less Traveled

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg promoted his accomplishments yesterday and provided a peek into his agenda for the coming year. His plans include a campaign against gun crimes, a tax rebate for homeowners and an end to the practice of social promotion for third graders in the public schools. He spoke at length about overdevelopment on Staten Island and
title: Mayor Offers Coming Attractions on Safety, Taxes and Schools

author: E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com
body: Cold-Water Flat Days Q. I'm fascinated by the old Public Baths building on Huron Street in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. What is its history and what is the current state of its interior? A. When the Huron Street Public Bath opened at 139 Huron in 1904, it answered what was seen as a genuine public health need. Two years earlier, The Brooklyn Daily Eagle
title: F.Y.I.
